'''OLED model:''' {{cvt|640|g}} | website = {{URL|steamdeck.com}} }} The '''Steam Deck''' is a [[Handheld PC|handheld]] [[gaming computer]] produced by [[Valve Corporation]], designed to run the large library of games available on the [[Steam (service)|Steam]] storefront client. Built upon the experiences gained from Valve's earlier ventures with [[Steam Machine (computer)|Steam Machine]] and the [[Steam Controller]], the Steam Deck integrates a custom [[AMD APU]] and [[SteamOS]], a [[Linux Distribution|Linux-based operating system]]. The Steam Deck represents Valve's pivot towards a fully internal hardware development approach, following the challenges faced with Steam Machines' reliance on external manufacturers and the requirement for native [[Linux gaming|Linux game]] support. Since its release in February 2022, the Steam Deck has garnered significant attention for its widespread adoption and versatility, including support for both native Linux games and those running through [[Proton (software)|Proton]], a compatibility layer for [[Windows]] games. Additionally, the Steam Deck features a desktop mode and allows users to install third-party [[Linux]] applications. The device has seen multiple revisions, including the introduction of [[OLED screen]] models in November 2023. Despite criticism regarding battery life, the Steam Deck has achieved notable commercial success, selling millions of units and influencing the market with its approach to portable gaming, and has spurred interest in similar handheld gaming computers. ==History== Valve's [[Steam Machine (hardware platform)|Steam Machine]] series of gaming computers using [[Linux]]-based [[SteamOS]] was introduced in 2015, which worked their way into the conception of the Steam Deck. Valve quietly pulled back on it by April 2018, but stated they remained committed to providing some type of open-hardware platform.{{Cite web |last=Phillips |first=Tom |date=April 4, 2018 |title='It's true Steam Machines aren't exactly flying off the shelves' |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-04-04-its-true-steam-machines-arent-exactly-flying-off-the-shelves |access-date=April 4, 2018 |website=[[Eurogamer]] |archive-date=December 7, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181207105453/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-04-04-its-true-steam-machines-arent-exactly-flying-off-the-shelves |url-status=live }} Steam Deck designer Scott Dalton said "there was always kind of this classic [[chicken and egg problem]] with the Steam Machine", as it required the adoption of Linux by both players and game developers to reach a critical interest in the machines to draw manufacturers in making them.{{Cite web |last=Marks |first=Tom |date=July 30, 2021 |title=Valve Explains How The Failure of Steam Machines Helped Build The Steam Deck |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-explains-how-it-learned-from-past-mistakes |access-date=July 30, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=March 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220320055430/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-explains-how-it-learned-from-past-mistakes |url-status=live }} The lack of Linux game availability during the lifetime of Steam Machines led Valve to invest development into [[Proton (software)|Proton]], a Linux compatibility layer to allow Windows–based games to be run on Linux without modification. Some of the early prototypes of Valve's [[Steam Controller]], also released in 2015, included a small LCD screen within the middle of the controller which could be programmed as a second screen alongside the game that the user was playing. One idea from this prototype was to include the [[Steam Link]], a device capable of streaming game content from a computer running Steam to a different monitor, here routing that output to the small LCD on the controller. This was later considered by Valve a very early concept behind the Steam Deck. Furthermore, their experience with trying to convince other manufacturers to produce Steam Machines led Valve to realize that it was better to develop all their hardware internally. Dalton said, "More and more it just became kind of clear, the more of this we are doing internally, the more we can kind of make a complete package." Rumors that Valve was working on a portable gaming unit had emerged in May 2021, based on updates made within the Steam code pointing towards a new "SteamPal" device, and comments made by Gabe Newell related to Valve developing games for consoles. ''[[Ars Technica]]'' had been able to confirm that new hardware was in development at Valve.{{Cite web |last=Mackovech |first=Sam |date=May 25, 2021 |title=Exclusive: Valve is making a Switch-like portable gaming PC |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2021/05/exclusive-valve-is-making-a-switch-like-portable-gaming-pc/ |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716082418/https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2021/05/exclusive-valve-is-making-a-switch-like-portable-gaming-pc/ |url-status=live }} Valve revealed the Steam Deck on July 15, 2021. The Deck, existing in three different models based on internal storage options, was shipped starting in February 2022 in North America and Europe, with other regions to follow throughout the year.{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Valve's gaming handheld is called the Steam Deck and it's shipping in December |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/15/22578783/valve-steam-deck-gaming-handheld-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716070029/https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/15/22578783/valve-steam-deck-gaming-handheld-pc |url-status=live }}{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=November 10, 2021 |title=Steam Deck launch delayed by two months |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/11/10/22774888/steam-deck-delayed-two-months-february-2022-launch-shipping |access-date=November 10, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=November 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211113043604/https://www.theverge.com/2021/11/10/22774888/steam-deck-delayed-two-months-february-2022-launch-shipping |url-status=live }} Valve's CEO, [[Gabe Newell]], said of the Steam Deck's approach, "As a gamer, this is a product I've always wanted. And as a game developer, it's the mobile device I've always wanted for our partners."{{Cite web |last=Schreier |first=Jason |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Nintendo Switch Gets New Rival With Valve's Portable Steam Console |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-15/nintendo-switch-gets-new-rival-with-valve-s-portable-console |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |archive-date=November 27, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221127072916/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-15/nintendo-switch-gets-new-rival-with-valve-s-portable-console |url-status=live }} According to Newell, they wanted to be "very aggressive" on the release and pricing strategy as they considered the mobile market as their primary competitor for the Deck. However, their focus was on the unit's performance; Newell stated, "But the first thing was the performance and the experience, [that] was the biggest and most fundamental constraint that was driving this."{{Cite web |last=Bailey |first=Kat |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell: Hitting Steam Deck Price Was 'Painful' but 'Critical' |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-price-valve-gabe-newell-400-dollars-painful-but-critical |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716113821/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-price-valve-gabe-newell-400-dollars-painful-but-critical |url-status=live }} Newell recognized that the base pricing was somewhat lower than expected and "painful", but necessary to meet the expectation of gamers who would want the Deck. Newell continued that he believed this was a new product category of personal computer hardware that Valve and other computer manufacturers would continue to participate in if the Steam Deck proved successful, and thus it was necessary to keep the unit's price point reasonable to demonstrate viability.{{Cite web |last=Chalk |first=Andy |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell expects Steam Deck to sell 'millions of units' but the pricing was 'painful' to pick |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/gabe-newell-expects-steam-deck-to-sell-millions-of-units-but-the-pricing-was-painful-to-pick/ |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716070837/https://www.pcgamer.com/gabe-newell-expects-steam-deck-to-sell-millions-of-units-but-the-pricing-was-painful-to-pick/ |url-status=live }} The openness of the system was also a key feature according to Newell, as that is a defining "superpower" of the personal computer space over typical console systems. Newell did not want to have any limitations on what the end user could do with the hardware, such as installing alternate non-Steam software on it.{{Cite web |last=Skrebeles |first=Joe |date=July 28, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell Pushes Back Against Closed Platforms, Says Openness is 'PC's Superpower' |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-openness-superpower-closed-platforms-gabe-newell |access-date=July 29, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=November 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116152131/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-openness-superpower-closed-platforms-gabe-newell |url-status=live }} As of December 2022,{{Update inline|date=August 2023}} Valve was pursuing improvements on the Steam Deck, including per-game "power profiles", and some other performance improvements, as well as evaluating a second generation Steam Deck. Valve was also considering bringing some of the Steam Deck technology into a new Steam Controller 2.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=December 15, 2022 |title=Valve answers our burning Steam Deck questions — including a possible Steam Controller 2 |url=https://www.theverge.com/23499215/valve-steam-deck-interview-late-2022 |access-date=December 20, 2022 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=January 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230109235431/https://www.theverge.com/23499215/valve-steam-deck-interview-late-2022 |url-status=live }} Valve announced two new Deck models to be available for purchase in November 2023, both with OLED screens, extended battery capacity, and improved cooling features, but otherwise no changes to internal components. These models replace two of the existing models.{{cite web | url = https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/a-new-oled-version-of-the-steam-deck-has-been-announced/ | title = A new OLED version of the Steam Deck has been announced | first = Chris | last = Scullion | date = November 9, 2023 | accessdate = November 9, 2023 | work = [[Video Games Chronicle]] | archive-date = August 24, 2024 | Valve stated that they would have wanted to include OLED screens for the original launch models, but at the time, OLED screens of sufficient size and quality did not yet exist on the market, and they would have had to delay release by 12 to 18 months if they went on that route.{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2023/11/why-we-had-to-wait-nearly-two-years-for-an-oled-steam-deck/ | designer Lawrence Yang said they wanted to wait for a "generational leap" of CPUs with better computing power without significant power requirement increases before implementing a new version of the Steam Deck.https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2024/10/valve-still-waiting-on-a-generational-leap-for-steam-deck-2-but-its-coming/ ==Hardware== ===LCD models=== The original Steam Deck was launched in February 2022 and included a custom [[AMD APU]] based on their [[Zen 2]] and [[RDNA 2]] architectures, named Aerith, after the ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' character [[Aerith Gainsborough]].{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=November 12, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: Five big things we learned from Valve's developer summit |url=https://www.theverge.com/22779252/steam-deck-things-we-learned-from-valve-developer-summit |access-date=November 12, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=February 7, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220207230831/https://www.theverge.com/22779252/steam-deck-things-we-learned-from-valve-developer-summit |url-status=live }} The CPU runs a four-core/eight-thread unit and the GPU runs on eight [[compute unit]]s with a total estimated performance of 1.6 TFLOPS. Both the CPU and GPU use variable timing frequencies, with the CPU running between 2.4 and 3.5 GHz and the GPU between 1.0 and 1.6 GHz based on current processor needs. Valve stated that the CPU has comparable performance to [[Ryzen 3000]] desktop computer processors and the GPU performance to the [[Radeon RX 6000 series]]. The Deck includes 16 GB of [[LPDDR5]] [[RAM]] in a quad-channel configuration, with a total bandwidth of 88 GB/s.{{Cite web |last=Loeffler |first=John |date=July 21, 2021 |title=Steam Deck gets a spec update, and it's good news for gamers |url=https://www.techradar.com/news/steam-deck-gets-a-spec-update-and-its-good-news-for-gamers |access-date=July 22, 2021 |website=[[TechRadar]] |archive-date=March 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230316224310/https://www.techradar.com/news/steam-deck-gets-a-spec-update-and-its-good-news-for-gamers |url-status=live }} [[File:Close view of Steam Deck D-pad and analogue stick (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Close view of the Steam Deck directional pad, thumbstick, and portion of trackpad]] The Deck's main unit is designed for handheld use. It includes a {{convert|7|in|mm|adj=on}} touchscreen [[LCD]] display with a 1280×800 pixel resolution with a fixed 60 Hz [[refresh rate]]; games are configured to use [[Screen tearing#Vertical synchronization|vertical synchronization]] where possible. The unit's input set features two thumbsticks, a directional pad, ABXY buttons, two shoulder buttons on each side of the unit, four additional buttons on the rear of the unit, as well as two trackpads under each thumbstick.{{Cite web |last=Moore |first=Bo |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: The First Hands-On With Valve's Handheld Gaming PC |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-hands-on-impressions-details-valve-handheld-gaming-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716113026/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-hands-on-impressions-details-valve-handheld-gaming-pc |url-status=live }} The thumbsticks and trackpads use [[capacitive sensing]], and the unit further includes a [[gyroscope]] to allow for more specialized controls on the handheld mode. The unit also includes [[Haptic technology|haptic feedback]]. The Deck supports [[Bluetooth]] connectivity for input devices, including common game controllers, and includes integrated [[WiFi]] network support to meet [[IEEE 802.11]]a/b/g/n/ac standards,{{Cite web |last=Phillips |first=Tom |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Valve announces Steam Deck, a £349 handheld PC |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2021-07-15-valve-announces-steam-deck-a-gbp349-handheld-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[Eurogamer]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716063002/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2021-07-15-valve-announces-steam-deck-a-gbp349-handheld-pc |url-status=live }}{{Cite web |last=McCaffery |first=Ryan |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Steam Deck FAQ: Valve Answers the Biggest Questions |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-faq-big-questions-answered |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=July 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210716073539/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-faq-big-questions-answered |url-status=live }} stereo sound out via a [[digital signal processor]], an integrated microphone and a headphone jack, a 40 watt-hour battery, which Valve estimates that for "lighter use cases like game streaming, smaller 2D games, or web browsing" can last between seven and eight hours. Valve also estimated that by keeping frame rates to around 30 [[frames per second]] (FPS) more intensive games such as ''[[Portal 2]]'' could be played for five to six hours. The system's software includes an optional FPS limiter that balance a game's performance to optimize battery life.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=July 25, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck has an 'optional built-in FPS limiter' for better battery life |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/25/22593079/valve-steam-deck-fps-limiter-target-performance-battery-life |access-date=July 25, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=March 21, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230321124319/https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/25/22593079/valve-steam-deck-fps-limiter-target-performance-battery-life |url-status=live }} At release, Steam Decks were only manufactured in a black casing to reduce the complexity of production, though Valve stated that they have considered introducing other case colors or themes in the future.{{Cite web |last=Wickens |first=Katie |date=August 6, 2021 |title=Valve says there is 'tons of opportunity' around different colours for future Steam Decks |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-colour-scheme-discussions-interview-coomer/ |access-date=August 6, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=November 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116152132/https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-colour-scheme-discussions-interview-coomer/ |url-status=live }} Valve partnered with [[iFixit]] to provide replacement parts for users.{{Cite web |last=Fenlon |first=Wes |date=February 15, 2022 |title=Valve is partnering with iFixit to sell Steam Deck replacement parts |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-is-partnering-with-ifixit-to-sell-steam-deck-replacement-parts/ |access-date=February 15, 2022 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=February 16, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220216000841/https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-is-partnering-with-ifixit-to-sell-steam-deck-replacement-parts/ |url-status=live }} The unit shipped in three models based on internal storage options. The base model includes a 64 GB [[eMMC]] internal storage unit, running over [[PCI Express 2.0|PCI Express 2.0 x1]]. A mid-tier model includes 256 GB of storage through an [[NVMe]] SSD device, while the high-end unit includes a 512 GB NVMe SSD storage unit, with the latter two both shipping with drives that run [[PCI Express 3.0|PCI Express 3.0 x4]]. All 3 [[Stock keeping unit|SKUs]] use the same [[M.2]] 2230 interface for internal storage. Valve stated that the built-in storage is not meant to be replaceable by end-users, though can be replaced as necessary for repair.{{Cite web |last=Moore |first=Bo |date=July 21, 2021 |title=Steam Deck SSD is Upgradeable, But It Won't Be Easy |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-ssd-upgradeable-valve |access-date=July 21, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=May 29, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230529085717/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-ssd-upgradeable-valve |url-status=live }} Additional storage space is available through a [[microSD]] card slot, which also supports [[microSDXC]] and [[microSDHC]] formats. As Valve considered options for bringing a handheld device to market, they set a priority that the device had to be able to play nearly the entirety of the Steam game catalogue, and rejected possible hardware that moved away from the standard [[x86]]-based processing structure that would have been easier to implement in handheld form but would have limited what games would be available. Only through recent discussions with AMD and their current product lines was Valve able to identify a technical approach that would meet the goal of a handheld device capable of playing all Steam games without overtaxing the processor unit.{{Cite web |last=Castle |first=Katherine |date=August 24, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck interview: Valve's designers on all things hardware, software, and knowing when to stop |url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/the-steam-deck-interview-valves-designers-on-all-things-hardware-software-and-knowing-when-to-stop |access-date=August 24, 2021 |website=[[Rock Paper Shotgun]] |archive-date=November 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116152129/https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/the-steam-deck-interview-valves-designers-on-all-things-hardware-software-and-knowing-when-to-stop |url-status=live }} The developers considered the Steam Deck to be [[future-proof]]. While SteamOS had been previously developed for Steam Machines using [[Debian]] Linux, Valve stated that they wanted to use a [[Rolling release|rolling upgrade]] approach for the Deck's system software, a function Debian was not designed for, but which is a characteristic of Arch Linux.{{Cite web |last=Dexter |first=Alan |date=August 9, 2021 |title=This is why Valve is switching from Debian to Arch for Steam Deck's Linux OS |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/this-is-why-valve-is-switching-from-debian-to-arch-for-steam-decks-linux-os/ |access-date=August 9, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=May 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230526185646/https://www.pcgamer.com/this-is-why-valve-is-switching-from-debian-to-arch-for-steam-decks-linux-os/ |url-status=live }} An [[application programming interface]] (API) specific for the Steam Deck is available to game developers, allowing a game to specify certain settings if it is being run on a Steam Deck compared to a normal computer.{{Cite web |last=Ridley |first=Jacob |date=August 6, 2021 |title=Valve is creating a Steam Deck API for devs to quickly optimise games |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-api-optimisation/ |access-date=August 6, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=January 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230128165951/https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-api-optimisation/ |url-status=live }} Within the Steam storefront, developers can populate a special file depot for their game with lower-resolution textures and other reduced elements to allow their game to perform better on the Steam Deck; Steam automatically detects and downloads the appropriate files for the system (whether on a computer or Steam Deck) when the user installs the game. ===Interface=== [[File:Steam Deck Steam UI.jpg|thumb|left|The library page for the Steam client used on the Steam Deck. [[Epic Games]]' [[Tim Sweeney (game developer)|Tim Sweeney]] and [[Xbox Game Studios]]' [[Phil Spencer (business executive)|Phil Spencer]] complimented Valve on the Steam Deck, with Sweeney calling it an "amazing move by Valve!"{{Cite web |last=Chalk |first=Andy |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Tim Sweeney: Steam Deck is 'an amazing move by Valve' |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/uk/tim-sweeney-steam-deck-is-an-amazing-move-by-valve/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]] |archive-date=November 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116152130/https://www.pcgamer.com/uk/tim-sweeney-steam-deck-is-an-amazing-move-by-valve/ |url-status=live }} Spencer congratulated Valve "on getting so many of us excited to be able to take our games with us wherever we decide to play".{{Cite web |last=Watts |first=Steve |date=July 16, 2021 |title=Microsoft 'Always Excited' About Things Like Steam Deck, But No Game Pass Commitment Yet |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/microsoft-always-excited-about-things-like-steam-deck-but-no-game-pass-commitment-yet/1100-6494040/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[GameSpot]] |archive-date=November 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116152130/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/microsoft-always-excited-about-things-like-steam-deck-but-no-game-pass-commitment-yet/1100-6494040/ |url-status=live }} Many outlets compared the unit to that of the [[Nintendo Switch]], generally recognized as the first true hybrid video game console. Valve stated that they did not really consider the Switch in designing the Deck, as they "tried to make all the decisions really in Steam Deck that targeted that audience and that served the customers that were already having a good time interacting with the games that are on that platform, on our platform", and that by happenstance, came out with a device that was similar in function to the Switch.{{Cite web |last=Bailey |first=Kat |date=July 23, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: Valve Says It Never Really Compared Its Handheld to Switch |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-switch-comparison-gabe-newell-valve |access-date=July 23, 2021 |website=[[IGN]] |archive-date=July 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210726130439/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-switch-comparison-gabe-newell-valve |url-status=live }} ''[[The Verge]]'' stated that the Steam Deck was generally a more powerful machine compared to the Switch but that power came with a tradeoff in battery life which was greater with the Switch.
